So all these things are in play, but it doesn't mean that we should be derelict in our duty to do an examination of the sheriff's department, just like we've done in the FBI, to make sure that the right protocols in place. To make sure that this doesn't happen again. That is healthy, it is responsible, and it is competency. And that's what we need to focus on here. So all of this is appropriate discussion, just like we should discuss the sheriff here, Israel, and whether or not he's the right person to be doing that job. I think the answer is clear.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, when we talk about diversions and political agendas, it's like the NRA discount story is kind of like a diversion away. Everybody here at this table and Donald Trump at his listening event, there's everything from civil tags to hardening soft targets. How does banning NRA discounts are getting rid of that, how does that help?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So United Airlines enterprise, rent-a-car, I think Hertz joined in, and now Delta. And so, in this scenario, I understand there's going to be opposition to the NRA. Just like there's opposition to Planned Parenthood, like the mirror organization for ideology. But in this situation, when you -- we've talk about see-something, say-something, should lead to do-something. And we know that the do-something did not happen in this case. So why would you take that out on dues paying members of the NRA who want to rent a car from you. Why are you punishing them? It doesn't make sense. And then it gets even worse, I think, because now an elected official in Georgia is saying, oh, yeah, Delta, we're going to come back at you and take away your tax break. Like, this is actually going to lead nowhere because a corporation has the right to make a decision. If they want to lose customers, fine. If it means that much to them and they want to take the P.R. hit for it, or maybe they think they get good P.R. out of this, they've made that calculation as a business. I don't think the government should come in then and try to punish them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And lastly, this sheriff is the reason why people want to arm themselves because they don't believe the sheriff can protect their safety, as they didn't this time. They weren't able to protect themselves.

Somebody should look into it because what they did is really fraudulent, and somebody should be looking into that. And by somebody, I'm talking about you know who.

His own FBI said they had grave concerns. Why? Because it was going to undermine the FISA court and you have to put out dockets. utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So what do you think about the Dem memo? Do you think it helps their case or do you think it just muddies the water?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think it muddies the water. I don't know, necessarily -- meaning the Democrats case?

They tried to delegitimize the presidency. He's at war with the press. He's frustrated. So this is just another example where he feels that people are trying to obfuscate issues. And make it difficult for the American people to understand, even as bright as they are, what's going on here. This is really just an example of politics not really working at its best in D.C., and that was the whole drain the swamp movement, right, because that's what we're seeing here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

One of the things Juan mentioned was that the dossier really didn't play any role in the FISA application, and that they had verified all this stuff when they made the application. utterances.sentences: I have to admit that our memo is bigger than their memo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This game of rock, paper, scissors. Nunes' was paper and they were rock. Paper goes over rock in case you remember. They claim that they counter the Republican accusation of abuse, but it's -- they use the word speculate. That they speculated that they knew where the dossier -- that's not a reputation. A speculation is not a reputation. This is like me trying to return a serve from Venus Williams. It just went nowhere. I think the Democrats need to find an alternative path to work because Russia isn't going to get you to the office.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree with that, that the Democrats need a method of some sort going into the midterms, and Russia cannot be it if they expect to win, although they do have a lot of energy on their side. I read three articles on each side, and to me it's a wash. I look at it and I think that one thing we don't have here is that there are four FISA court judges. We have the application. We don't have the conversation during the appearance in front of the judges. What did they ask them? What were the answers? We have no idea and I don't necessarily that we need to know. The other thing that this one does is to say that there were several of these people on the Trump campaign -- I'm not saying President Trump knew - - how would he have known that they were already under investigation? He wouldn't necessarily have known that. That Manafort, and Gates, and Page and these characters have this problem before they even join the campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, one thing the Democratic memo does not do -- it clearly says that they told the FISA judge that Hillary and the DNC paid for it. They did not tell the FISA court judge. They buried that information. At no point was the judge made aware that Hillary and the DNC paid for this political dossier.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wrong. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

Maxine Waters, the Democratic congresswoman from California, took the stage this weekend at the convention to drum up support for building a unified blue wave in November. And she's still not letting up on President Trump.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: Democrats, I don't care what the Republicans say. I say impeach 45. Impeach 45. Impeach 45. Impeach 45. My gun is bigger than your gun. utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Pretty strong. Dana, let's go to what I think was big news this weekend. You get an 84-year-old senator, Dianne Feinstein, not endorsed by her party as she seeks a fifth term in the U.S. senate.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You think about the Bernie Burroughs during the last election. There's a real pull between the pragmatists of the Democratic Party where there's a shrinking number, and the progressives. And in California, progressive is where you really want to be if you want to succeed in Democratic politics right now. You think of Tom Steyer and Nancy Pelosi. Like, she continues to give Republicans a lot of -- to run against her. So I think that -- I wouldn't say that Feinstein is not going to win. I mean, if she wins the primary, she's probably going to win because the Republican Party is so decimated there. But I do think that this loose talk about impeachment absolutely helps President Trump. Maybe not himself in his approval ratings, but it will galvanize Republicans to go out and support other Republicans in order to prevent that. You can't impeach somebody just because you don't like them or that their rhetoric isn't good. And in fact, I would say that there's one Democrat really making this point. Susan Glasser interviewed Congressman Jerry Nadler in The New Yorker. And so he was head of the Judiciary Committee, and it would be up to him. And he said, "My view of impeachment is to be very careful that when Tom Steyer is saying 'I will only give you money if you pledge that you will vote for impeachment,'" that that -- that Nadler says that is very premature. So I feel like the elders of the Democratic Party are trying to tap the brakes on this, because they realize it's not the path to victory. And you cannot impeach someone because you don't like his Twitter account.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, Kimberly, just to quickly finish up on the Dianne Feinstein point...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... she got 37 percent of support from the Democrats in California this weekend. Fifty-seven percent, just below the 60 percent threshold that would have won him the endorsement...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... went to Kevin Delong, who's the Senate leader in California. And the key issue that apparently differentiates the two is Delong's support for immigrants.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, OK, so you know it's pretty appalling that I know Dianne Feinstein very, very well for really, I guess, the majority of my entire existence on the planet. And I know her well from San Francisco, and she's, you know, been a tireless public advocate. I find her to be one of the more reasonable Democrats, which is probably why they are not supporting her. Because she's actually very good about the United States military, national security, foreign policy, has common sense as it relates to the economy, the tax issues. And so they want to go so far left and so liberal that they're going to do -- they're going to seek out people like that. They want people who are like bomb throwers. But it's going to really fracture and alienate, I think, a lot of voters that might've gone Democrat. This new kind of, like, platform the Democratic Party has. And so, you know, I think it's disappointing that they're doing this. Obviously, immigration is something that's like a hot-button issue right now. But it just goes to show you Democrats don't even know a winner when they see one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, do you think it's a legitimate argument to say, "Well, it's five terms. She's, you know, 84."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Ageist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, if people don't think she's fit at that age, then they can primary her out of there. It doesn't really bother me that much. I just think the Democrats...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: How about Pelosi?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The whole platform of "I'm going to take your guns. Let's impeach Trump and Russia, Russia, Russia," is a garbage platform. And it's not going to do anything for the Democrats if they want to take back the House. Trump's at 50 [SIC] percent approval. The economy is humming. Russia is not...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And then the Russia stuff doesn't move the needle. It might motivate a small portion of the people. But that's fine. That wasn't the CPAC poll, by the way. That's the...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm just thinking of the other ones this morning.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. And listen, they can motivate a certain part of the Democratic base with that stuff. That's not going to get them over the hump. Democrats have almost ceded the economy to the Republicans, because none of them voted for the tax cuts. utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Guns.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. They lost the House trying to take back guns before. I don't know if they're going to make the same mistake again. They very well might. But the polls right now show an even race in the congressional midterms. So Democrats right now, they're in deep, deep trouble. They know it, and they haven't learned any lessons from the 2016 election.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Sometimes I worry about where you get your information. But I want to -- I want to go to Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Sometimes?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know, I don't know. So I want to go to Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because Greg, I wanted you to comment on Maxine Waters and the "Impeach 45." Is that going to be a new slogan? Will we get hats?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, we'll get hats.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: T-shirts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, the thing is, I want them to continue down this path, because the best -- the best way you can elect your adversary is be irrational about how much -- like, if you are irrational in your anti- Trumpism, it will only help them. The same way calling Obama a Kenyan-born interloper helps Obama. Like the more -- every party has...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You did that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: ... an extreme. Yes, but I was doing it -- I was doing it to mock people who believed that. Unfortunately, they didn't know I was mocking them. But -- and here's a serious point about this whole impeachment thing. Remember what happened after the Clinton impeachment? Something called 9/11. It's a correlation not an observation. I mean, it's barely a correlation. It's an observation. But it's the kind of political distraction we choose that ends up ignoring certain catastrophic threats before us. If we get so bogged down in this stuff, we don't see the other things in front of us. And you could argue, like, Clinton was so, like -- he spent all his time trying to cover up the stuff he was doing and he didn't see what was coming down the pike.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Also what happened to Clinton's approval rating when they tried impeachment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. A California mayor feels it's her duty to keep ICE from doing their duty. She's tipping off illegals that the feds are coming. Next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Not only is California unwilling to help the Trump administration curb illegal immigration, one mayor just took steps to warn illegals the feds were coming. Democratic Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf put out a press release this weekend to sound the alarm about potential ICE raids in her city before they happened. She says it was her ethical obligation to do so.

utterances.speaker: MAYOR LIBBY SCHAAF (D), OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA
utterances.sentences: My priority is to keep this community safe. It is not my wish to panic people but to ensure that they're prepared with information. Residents should know that they do not have an obligation to open their door if an ICE official knocks. While I am very committed to being a law-abiding citizen, I feel confident that my sharing this information, because I did not receive it through official channels, is legal and frankly, it's my ethical obligation. I felt that it was my duty to share the information.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Hmm, mm, mm. All right. Well, consulted with a lawyer, clearly. No word about the ethical obligation Schaaf has to protect the legal United States citizens in her city. The move came days after the president warned that he may pull ICE agents from the state, which refuses habitually, to cooperate. So let's go California, shall we?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I have a solution, as always, to the great problems of this world. The Mexican president is angry at Donald Trump about the wall. California wants to do its own thing independently as a sanctuary state. Remember the Louisiana Purchase? I do. Sell California to Mexico.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: We'd owe money.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no, no. I did the math. You sell California to Mexico for 47.5 trillion. They could pay it off over 25 years, Mexico. We'd take 10 trillion, thrown that into the budget, and announce a three- year tax holiday for the remaining 49 states. You don't pay any taxes, because we got it from Mexico. And then the remaining 37.5 trillion goes against solving world -- major issues like hunger, poverty, air pollution, which costs 2.5 trillion a year, for 15 years that's 37.5 trillion. The Mexican officials and police can now deal with California, gang crime, and their bankrupt cities and their economic inequality. We get tax breaks, and the world conquers all of its problems. This is the answer. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness. All right, coming to a briefing room near you soon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Probably not.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, probably not. I'm a little bit worried about the massive amount of debt that California has but, OK, if you did the math. That's enough to pay that off. OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's -- let's just say this is another hypothetical situation. That there's going to be a drug bust, and somebody in the Justice Department or the FBI knows about the drug bust that's coming, and they give a heads up to the people so that they scatter. How wrong would that be?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Who goes to jail?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: To me, that's the same thing. They're here illegally. They should have to suffer the consequences for that. I actually think that the Democrats, if they want to push back on immigration, these stories about parents and children being separated at the border and held miles apart, unable to see each other. There was one story today of an African woman who has not seen her 6-year-old daughter in several weeks. And I think that's a much stronger play for them. Not this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I totally agree. I mean, but sometimes you just wonder where the common sense goes. All right, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Common sense goes here, Kimberly. You're going to...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: People will say that I'm his new mother.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: He got a mom text.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're a mother from another mother.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Exactly, a brother from another mother. There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Juan would disown me. There's going to be a lot of these anti-Trump superheroes who are going to pop up, like this person in California, like Rahm Emanuel, who kind of want to earn their street cred by fighting the system and fighting Donald Trump. You get a lot of free publicity. And they can survive it, because they're in left-wing precincts. But I don't think it's good for the country. She's breaking the law. U.S. Code 1234 -- you cannot conceal, harbor or shield from protection an illegal alien. You can face fines or imprisonment, up to five years. Although she's never going to jail. It's amazing how the Democratic Party has changed their platform over the last couple decades. This party a couple years ago voted for the border fence, voted to, you know, not shield illegal aliens from protection, voted for sweeps, voted for raids. Now it's just open season. Let them in, give them free stuff. Never prosecute them. It's amazing. They're not the party of law and order any more. And Trump, when he fights the federal government, when he thinks things are wrong, he's called a traitor. When the Democrats do it, they're heroes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the -- a couple of things. One is big news when you have the Supreme Court of the United States decline to look at the DREAMer situation. It means that the March deadline is not going to be in place. The second thing to say is, I think that what the mayor of Oakland is doing is saying even if you are here illegally, there are certain steps. Like, you don't have to open your door. You don't have to do X, Y, Z. That's information that's given out by everybody. That's not breaking the law. That's not supporting people being here illegally. And I think that's an important distinction to be heard.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. Are you feeling super stressed?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sell California!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow. Are you feeling super stressed out like a lot of other Americans? One writer has an interesting take on who's to blame, what's to blame, next. Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Americans are anxious and exhausted, more so than usual, according to a new study. Sixty-three percent cite the future of the nation as a stressor. USA Today columnist points to a long list of contributing factors, like mass shootings, natural disasters and also, quote, "travel bans, minority groups in the crosshairs of the Trump administration, or patients with catastrophic illnesses threatened by the loss of health care. Such fears are real and specific." And Greg, certainly, that is true for some people. But overall, we talked about this last week, how we have a theory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: About the worries -- like, why you worry about the future.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think it's an evolutionary module in your brain, because you want to live longer. So you just naturally worry even when things are good. But the exhaustion that this person is talking about is caused by our own inability to shut off content, right, from our phones. It's not about the story itself but the quantity of the stories. This guy is blaming his liberal exhaustion on the right, but he's actually just losing. And that's exhausting when you're losing. But you know what it is? You always feel sick and tired after the third trip to the buffet. And it's no different here, where you've got to put your phone down.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is the buffet.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Who goes three times?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do. And nobody feels worse when they go for a walk, unless you get run over by a teenager who's texting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's true. you never regret taking a walk. That's true. Well, yes, you wouldn't want that. But you never regret taking a walk. That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Especially if you have a dog.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, taking a social media break, maybe that can help people not be so stressed out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm stressed, because I work with Greg every day, and he's just very tiresome. But I've learned how to cope.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow, he was nice to you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what happened!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan doesn't bother me at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy in the green room over here. So I think...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Diva. Diva.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. We can talk about it in the "One More Thing" or in your case, two more things. I think this country -- this country is so soft right now. You had that civil rights movement, the Vietnam War in the '60s. You know, we got attacked Pearl Harbor, 9/11. Now we have -- things are so good now, as Greg -- this is buffet season. The travel ban, how many Americans does that affect? I don't think it affects any. I think maybe a handful. The DACA, people are anxious about that. That's 700,000 people in a country of 350 million. Enough. Go take a walk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, are you stressed and exhausted?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I feel exhausted. I do feel like -- I don't think there's ever been a time...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're getting over the flu.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's true. But I think in terms of the politics, people in Washington say to me, "Hey, you weren't around in the '60s, buddy."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The cities were burning. They were throwing this president out, this president -- I mean, you know, you couldn't -- the race relations were terrible. Everything. And I think, well, that's true. I wasn't around in the '60s like I am now, but I must say, right now, people -- it's not just me. The polls say 60 plus percent of Americans think that, you know...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, they also, Kimberly -- they worry about the future, because especially, maybe if you're worried about the industries of the future and what sort of jobs are going to be available and A.I. is coming and all of this stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Robots.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I don't worry about any of that. Greg is the one that has the nightmares, or maybe you call them dreams. Where I come to get you in the future.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Sarah Connor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You can just calm -- everybody can just calm down. Kimberly is on it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, no offense, I really am on it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She's on it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So I'm not stressed about any of that. Because I feel like a very good choice that I was put in charge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Indeed. All right. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, time for "One More Thing." Let's do this.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Diva News.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg Diva News."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. I realize that...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You stole my crown.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is not. It's my crown. You will never see it again. You know what? We divas have to stick together. So in this new segment, which will air every single day for the rest of my life, I will salute divas all over the world, including this one. Let's check her out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She refused to give up her seat to a dog. She said no. That is not just a diva, that is a strong female. And I salute that cat for not giving up her seat in true diva fashion.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Anything else, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. No more "One More Things."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Two more things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, a news anchor in San Diego, not Ron Burgundy. This woman had a visitor while she was on set. Let's look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: In for reading your garden of bugs or...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How is that for -- how is that for an introduction?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. We'll be right back. Bird day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We'll be talking about that next. Or now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They did a nice job winging that. Sorry, Greg. And, you know, nice job.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Really -- it's really getting mailed in today. Good thing mine is fantastic. So in political news, first lady Melania Trump spoke earlier today at the governors' luncheon for spouses at the White House, and she spoke about being encouraged by the young activists who have been speaking out in light of the Parkland shooting in Florida. She commended them on leading a movement geared towards gun violence prevention. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: MELANIE TRUMP, FIRST LADY
utterances.sentences: I have been heartened to see children across this country using their voices to speak out and try to create change. They're our future, and they deserve a voice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, true. We all talked about that one, about children getting involved and using their voice to express their feelings. She talked about how important it is that adults take responsibility in children having to manage the myriad of issues that they are faced with today.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, when it rains, it doesn't always have to pour. We had some good times this weekend. I want to show you my friend Bradley. He's two and a half. He's on a scooter. He just learned to use it. And we set up a race between him and Jasper.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he wanted -- and Bradley wanted to do it over and over again. Every time -- Jasper just won't let the kid win.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, Dana, you're making children cry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, he loved it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So basically, you just showed this tape to show your dog...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: ... beating the pants off a poor kid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are a terrible human being. Speaking of -- Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Here we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Segue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Cheap shot, cheap shot. Anyway, a weekend in heaven? No, but how about a weekend with my grandkids on Broadway? As you can imagine, twin 5-year-old American girls right now are pretty excited that previews of "Frozen: The Musical" have started on Broadway. So on Friday the family went to the show. The girls dressed up as Elsa and Anna.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Ah-na.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Ah-na. And to top it off, the next night we went to see "Spongebob Squarepants" on Broadway.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Young people love both, I've got to tell you. But the big surprise to me was how much they love Spongebob. And of course, they stopped by FOX. And I'm sure you come, as a loyal FOX viewer, knows how much FOX loves to make up the ladies. So here they are at makeup. A big thanks to you, Nicole. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's very sweet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This was a great weekend in New York. And Broadway...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And they sat still the whole time? They enjoyed it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. they loved it. Five-year-old girls in heaven.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's better than Greg when bailed out on me after I bought him a ticket to a Broadway show. And he left halfway through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Terrible, terrible play.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They ran out of wine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
